title.narrative: Informe de evaluación de medio término del proyecto COPS2
Revisión de Medio Término Proyecto Fortalecimiento de las Capacidades Nacionales para la Gestión y Reducción de las liberaciones de Contaminantes Orgánicos Persistentes (COP) en Honduras

description.narrative: Reducción de los riesgos a la salud y ambientales de los contaminantes orgánicos persistentes a través de la aplicación de los principios de la gestión ambientalmente racional
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Reduction in health and environmental risks of POPs through the application of principles of sound environmental management within the context of the National Implementation Plan for the Stockholm Convention
Degree of incorporation by key institutions of National Policy on sound management of hazardous chemicals and wastes, including POPs, in their activities.

comment.narrative: Key institutions do not have an effective coordination mechanism and the current one is not officially formalized. There is not an approved National Policy on chemicals to provide specific goals on Chemicals Management in Honduras, everyone works separately.
Actions related to sound chemical management included in operational plans of target institutions (SAG, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Labour, Ministry of Environment and Nartural Resources (SERNA)

The first General Assembly of the National Commission for Sound Management of Chemicals took place in February 2015. The Commission´s Board was set up, is led by the private sector, academy as Vice President and CESCCO as Secretary Executive. Standing committees were established in the areas of Pollutants Release and Transfer Registration, Chemical Emergency, Industrial Products, Pesticides, Monitoring and Evaluation among others. The Second Assembly of 2015 will be held in the month of November with the purpose of rendering implementation report of the Annual Work Plan and 2016 plan.

description.narrative: Quantity of POPs and pesticides contaminated with POPs in existence

comment.narrative: 18t (3.6t POPs pesticides and 14.4t of contaminated pesticides) are currently inventoried
No POPs pesticides or pesticides contaminated with POPs (0t) are reported.
0 tonnes of pesticides originally established in the Stockholm Convention are reported to date in Honduras.

description.narrative: Total mass of PCBs contaminated equipment (unused electrical transformers and capacitors contaminated with PCBs), that have been replaced and safely disposed of

comment.narrative: First inventory found 58t of disused equipment with PCBs and 138t still in use. Currently an estimated of 45t of equipment with PCBs are kept by the National Electric Power Company (ENEE), of which 42t (13t identified in first inventory without label information and 29t currently found) are disused and 3t are still in use. Additional amount still in use, remaining to be quantified by ENEE under WB project (PROMEF).

100% (58t) of disused equipment found in first inventory and (42t) of disused equipment currently found held by the National Electric Power Company (ENEE) are eliminated having a grand total of 100t to be disposed. The transformers currently in use will continue to be used with supervision, subject to eventual elimination after project end, additional amount of still in use transformers destroyed with World Bank (WB) funds.

A total of 112 tons of PCBs were exported to Spain in two exports registered in the month of May 2015. The case of electrical equipment will be decontaminated in Spain and oils incinerated in France. Currently as of June containers are in transit countries as recorded by the mobilization document of the Basel Convention. The certificate of final disposal will be available in August 2015.

description.narrative: Number of contaminated sites subject to remediation measures

comment.narrative: 5 contaminated sites with PCBs and 18 sites are considered as potentially contaminated with PCBs (1st Inventory); an additional site was found to date.
Remediation measures adopted in 6 pilot sites contaminated with PCBs and 6 pilot sites contaminated with POPs pesticides (5 storehouses and a containment area of a fruit company)

The project focused its actions to implement immediate measures to prevent and reduce risk, such as sealing three Storehouses and socializing the Management Plan of contaminated facilities with local authorities for the following sites:
Healh store house: Alto Verde,
Former health warehouse: Santa Maria del Real
School: José Cecilio del Valle With respect to the assessment done to 9 potentially contaminated sites with PCBs CESCCO jointly with project and ENEE presented the results of the assessment in each of these sites during the month July of 2015. These sites are considered as NON CONTAMINANTED with PCBs, action plans were given to ENEE to prevent future contamination of PCB and HC. Potentially exposed population (61 staff members of ENEE) was also sensitized about the risks of PCBs on health and environment.

description.narrative: Reduction in the emission of unintentionally produced POPs from the burning of solid waste and landfill fires

comment.narrative: The first inventory of dioxins and furans reported 400 g I-TEQ/year, only for the sub category of solid waste burning and fires in municipal dumps. Baseline figure to be confirmed

80 g I-TEQ/year reduction in UPOPs emitted from burning of solid waste and landfill fires (20% reduction over currently estimated baseline level). This target will be reassessed at the outset of the project implementation.

In the reporting period have been properly handled a total of 95552 tons of solid waste that were previously burned resulting in 89 g / TEQ are avoided to the environment. This represents a reduction of 22.4% in the reporting period. In the city of Siguatepeque and the Association of 5 Municipalities “COLOSUCA” the project has given support in awareness raising and evaluation of the compliance of the Solid Waste Master Plans with the aim of promoting the BAT/BEP related to waste management. These 6 municipalities are still pending of having international funding for the operation of regulated landfills (Spain has confirmed will support the construction of 3 landfills), meanwhile, the practice of open burning of waste has decreased with project support by developing training to municipal staff, optimization of waste collection service and awareness raising.

description.narrative: Existence of adequate Institutional capacities and regulatory and policy framework for the management and elimination of POPs and the reduction of their impacts
Percentage of budget requirements of lead authority (CESCCO) satisfied for analysis and regulatory roles

comment.narrative: CESCCO currently do not have self-sustaining financial resources or personnel resources to address the management of chemicals in Honduras.
100% of the budget requirements for CESCCO, for the exercise of its regulatory functions on chemicals, are satisfied.

The executive decree that created the National Commission for the Sound Management of Chemicals (Decree 035-2013) provided a framework for the Centre for the Study and Control of Pollutants (CESCCO) through the Secretariat of State for Energy, Environment, Natural Resources and Mines to request to Secretariat of Finance additional budget to CESCCO to strengthen the Department of Management of chemicals and the aforementioned commission. New parameters are offered by the CESCCO by direct action of the project: PCBs analyses in oil by two methods (chromatography and electrodes) as well as pesticide POPs chromatography) in priority environmental matrices. The project promoted the development and adoption of the Regulations for the environmentally sound management of PCBs (Ministerial Agreement 1071-2014) also produced the Handbook of the Best Environmental Practices for the Management of PCB equipment, which was approved by the Ministry of Environment. This has promoted CESCCO in the offering of PCB analysis to the public, as there is a demand based on the recently strengthened regulatory framework .

description.narrative: Frequency of meetings of National Management Committee (without GEF financial support)

comment.narrative: Meetings only held with external project support, for design of NIP enabling project and SAICM implementation plan having no specific national budget lines to be sustainable.
Medium Term Work Plan elaborated and 4 meetings held per year. Integration of sound management of chemicals in 4 key institutions.

In the month of February 2015 the first general assembly of the National Commission was developed, it is expected the second meeting in November 2015.
To date, the 10 standing committees have met, four (4) of them have been strengthened in this reporting period by the project (101 people in total have met): The PRTR committee (20 people trained); chemical emergencies committee (26); monitoring and evaluation committee (15); and pesticides management committee (30) have received training on each of their topics.

description.narrative: Existence and implementation of appropriate regulatory instruments and guidelines regarding solid waste management and chemicals management

comment.narrative: Regulatory Framework has gaps that prevent inter-agency coordination and clear guidelines on how to conduct a comprehensive management approach based in life cycle of chemicals. Lack of specific regulations for site remediation and hazardous waste management, as well as technical and practical guidelines for municipalities on solid waste management.

Regulatory instruments generated on:
-Management of Solid Waste -Implementation of PRTR, Management of Contaminated Sites
Technical Guides and standards on transport of Dangerous Goods, Storage of Industrial Chemicals, temporary storage of Hazardous Waste, environmental quality and remediation criteria for contaminated sites, sound management of PCBs and Solid Waste Management.

13 regulatory instruments have been generated which 8 have been socialized, 7 have been approved by the competent authorities, five have been published in the Official Gazette and are in compliance and 3 are under development. The instruments are: 1) A public Policy on chemicals (Decree PCM-029-2013) 2) National Commission of Chemicals (Decree 035-2013) 3) Regulation of equipment and wastes containing PCBs (Decree 1071-2013 ) and Manual for BEP for the Management of PCBs (Decree 1071-2013) and 5) Regulation of PRTR (Decree 1070-2014) 6) Functions Manual for the Department of Chemicals Management (approved) 7) Functions Manual for the Department of Solid Waste Management (approved) 8) Procedures Manual of the PRTR regulation (approved) 9) Regulation for the Management of Contaminated sites (developed, needs further socialization) 10) Procedures Manual for the Regulation for the Management of Contaminated Sites (made) 11) Technical Standard for Soil Quality (under development) 12) BAT / BEP Industrial Waste - Technical Guide (under technical review) and 13) Act of solid waste (under preparation).

description.narrative: Adequacy of procedures for monitoring effectiveness of management of POPs and other chemicals

comment.narrative: Currently does not operate a system of effective information exchange between possessors of POPs (and UPOPs releasers) and regulatory institutions. Conditions are unknown for hazardous waste and their holders.

Under the PRTR program, POP holders report their inventories and unintentional releases to the automated system. CESCCO maintains a database of holders of POPs and unintentional release of POPs sources .

POPs owners continue to report voluntarily to the CESCCO 2015 PRTR system. Recently PRTR regulation was published in the Official Gazette sectors subject to reporting and owners of POPs should report to PRTR in 2017 considering transfers and releases that occurred in 2016. In June 26 2015, the Secretary of Energy, Natural Resources, Environment and Mining published a notice of the obligation to report to the registration of PCBs and PRTR. In this report, transfers of POPs pesticides (60 tons) and PCBs (112 ton) that were exported for environmentally safe disposal abroad with project support will be reflected.

description.narrative: Percentage of laboratory analyses required to monitor the implementation of national policy on hazardous chemicals and wastes being carried on a cost recovery basis

comment.narrative: CESCCO currently is not sustainable, only 10% are being carried on a cost recovery basis
80% of laboratory analyses are being carried on a cost recovery basis (derived from the implementation of the National Policy).

The project facilitated the provision of strategic documents to achieve the increase in the percentage of total funds raised by the provision of CESCCO´s services. Of what is perceived by the payment of laboratory services in CESCCO, 70% is returned to sustainability in this area. New services such as PCB analysis by two methods (gas chromatography and electrode) and POPs pesticides by gas chromatography are now being offered by CESCCO. The project succeeded in the development of important instruments to improve CESCCO laboratory services. For example it was generated a methodology for calculating the actual costs of laboratory services , including new parameters to be offered (PCB and pesticide POPs). Also, a proposal for automated services provided by CESCCO was developed by the project. This improves the quality management system of the laboratory , streamlines processes and improves customer care .

description.narrative: Increased awareness regarding the nature, impacts and management of hazardous chemicals and wastes
Number of teachers in basic and intermediate education centers that have included the issue of chemicals management in their classes.

comment.narrative: Environment has been mainstreamed into the national educational curriculum, however there is no reference to the issue of teaching COPs, the chemical approach is contained only in pesticides.

350 Teachers of basic and middle level education of the priority regions (depending on the problem by chemicals at the national level) have approached the issue of Sound Management of Chemical in the Science class and other relevant subjects (environmental education).

The goal set by the project consisted of the design of educational material (Methodological Guide on chemicals management aimed at teachers) and training for 350 teachers from public educational institutions unofficial sector. This goal was surpassed for a total of more than 429 teachers in the area of Natural Sciences of primary and secondary education from nine departments. Additionally this educational material was officially approved by Ministerial Decree (Decree 24/04/13 and published in the Official Gazette March 12, 2014) for incorporation into teacher training materials. A delivery of 1,000 copies of the methodological guide for teachers of public schools with project support will be in the month of August 2015.

description.narrative: Number of postgraduate programmes that include aspects of risk management of hazardous chemicals in their pensum.

comment.narrative: No graduate program now considers the risk management for chemicals, there is only the risk management approach for natural phenomena.
At least a postgraduate programme incluiding chemical management in its curriculum.

description.narrative: Proportion of project beneficiaries in pilot sites who have increased awareness on the environmentally sound management of chemicals and pesticides with emphasis on the practice of not burning of wastes

comment.narrative: Awareness of chemical and waste issues is virtually inexistent (baseline to be defined precisely at project start)
170,000 people are awareness on the environmentally sound management of chemicals and pesticides with emphasis on the practice of not burning of wastes (criteria to be determined at project start)

The project developed an awareness campaign in three departments of Honduras (Comayagua, Cortés and Choluteca) directed a target audience of 170,000 people. The concept of the campaign was based on preventing the use of chemicals and not burning garbage reaching a goal of 1,445,000 people. This media campaign used local radio and national media, print media and knowledge fairs taking the issue of chemicals and not burn garbage. Highway´s billboards were installed with the message "Do not burn trash" on the main roads of the country, where about 10 000 vehicles circulating daily.

description.narrative: Numbers of staff members of key institutions with knowledge of chemicals management issues such as lifecycle management of chemicals, occupational safety, first aid for poisoning, management of contaminated sites

comment.narrative: 30 staff members of key institutions have knowledge of the management of chemicals that were strengthened in the framework of the Stockholm Convention enabling project and QSP SAICM project.-
120 members nationwide with knowledge of the management of chemicals including members of key government institutions, private sector and NGOs.

description.narrative: Sound environmental management and elimination of intentionally produced POPs
Number of sites subjected to detailed inventories of PCB stocks.

comment.narrative: Sites inventoried to date: Private sector 48 ENEE 70 Other public facilities 1 Total 119
Additional sites to be inventoried: Private sector 70 ENEE 20 Other public facilities 10 Total 100

The inventory of the public and private sector was completed, reporting a total of 211 tons of PCB containing equipment and wastes. Of the 211 tons, 112 tons of equipment and PCBs wastes were exported to Spain for environmentally safe disposal. 99 tonnes are still to be eliminated, which represent PCB equipment still in use.
It is expected though that the amount of PCB containing equipment might increase in the future, as decree 1070-2014, developed with support of the project, requires all equipment owners to report to CESCCO.
The National Electricity Company remains the principal owner of most PCB equipment, followed by the private sector and non ENEE institutions of the public sector.

description.narrative: Total mass of PCB equipment to which the private sector has made a commitment for replacement and disposal

comment.narrative: Current mass to be determined through inventories (5t found to date)
Commitments exist to eliminate 30t of PCBs equipment (subject to results of inventory)

With respect to private sector PCB owners, the mining company (Nyrstar) participated in the preparation of a plan for the management of PCB containing equipment (PCB equipment has now been inventoried) and implementation of a comprehensive plan to develop a more comprehensive inventory.
Technical assistance is being provided by the project’s staff and CESCCO to allow the private sector to gradually comply with the registration process established under the recently approvednational legislation.
NYSTAR is expected to submit its PCB management plan in August 2015 to the environment authority. The company will receive public recognition for its efforts.
One piece of electrical equipment with PCBs from the fruit company was reported in the inventory and was subsequently exported for disposal. PCB phase-out from the sugar company is still pending.

description.narrative: Number of storage sites containing or intended for POPs pesticides and PCBs in the country that have adequate conditions for safe temporary storage.

comment.narrative: One store house with regular conditions for the containment of pesticides POPs, one vault of the private sector that contains 3.5 tons of DDT. Four store houses with inadequate containment conditions of contaminated pesticides with POPs. 15 sites with disused equipment containing PCBs.

1 sites for centralization of equipment contaminated with PCBs to be financed by ENEE and 1 site for POPs contaminated pesticides to be financed by Ministry of Health, with adequate storage conditions, containing chemicals currently stored in other sites (POPs pesticides and the ones contaminated with POPs held in 4 storehouses.

A storage facility for PCB containing electrical waste equipment has been constructed with funding provided by the World Bank. It has received the authorization of the Municipality of Tegucigalpa and an environmental permit from the Ministry of Energy, Natural Resources, Environment and Mining. The storage/collection center will provide storage for PCB equipment from the south central region of the country. All of the POPs pesticides from El Guanabano (property of the Ministry of Health) were removed as well as all POPs pesticides from the storage facility of the Secretariat of Agriculture and Livestock (Nueva Aldea) were removed. Facilities were also decontaminated by the company contracted for the disposal of pesticides.

description.narrative: Number of members of staff of ENEE and private sector with knowledge of safe PCB management

comment.narrative: To be determined through staff surveys to be carried out at project start up
223 Employees of the ENEE have knowledge on the Environmentally Sound Management of waste and equipment containing PCBs

The project has trained 70 employees of ENEE, bringing the total number of people training in the management of PCB equipment to 200.
In August 2015, new training sessions will be developed to administrative and corporate communication staff (40 people).
The project expects to surpass its initial target to train 223 skilled employees.

description.narrative: Minimized releases of unintentionally produced POPs from current Waste Management practices.
Number of municipalities implementing Integral Management of Solid Waste.

comment.narrative: Currently all municipalities show weakness in the management of solid waste, open burning of wastes at the stage of final disposal prevails and there are limitations on the collection service, with backyard waste burning practices. Local governments do not have a comprehensive perspective on solid waste management.
5 municipal pilot projects developing Master Plans for integral management of solid wastes.

The project has continued to provide support for pilot municipalities (9 in total) to comply with the master plans for the integrated management of municipal solid waste that were formulated with project support.
It is noteworthy to report that due to the great empowerment that has resulted from the development of the master plans, the Secretary of Energy, Natural Resources and Environment issued a generic guide for developing solid waste master plans.
The Project has made efforts towards strengthening the technical committee members responsible for carrying out the actions of the master plans. The project has generated monitoring and evaluation instruments of solid waste master plans and trained local staff in its use (to date Comayagua and Tegucigalpa have been trained).

description.narrative: Reduction in the amount of solid wastes that are burnt

comment.narrative: Approximately 425.000 tons of domestic solid waste are burned.
The amount of solid waste burned is reduced by 20 %, which corresponds to 80 g TEQ or 85.000 t of solid waste not burned.

The capacity building has been fruitful in the sense that service coverage for waste collection in the pilot municipalities has been increased since training was provided, resulting in a higher volume of waste that is being disposed of at designed sites rather than burned in the open.
In this reporting period a total of 95,552 tons of solid waste has been properly handled that were previously burned: Comayagua (18,171.65 t); Tegucigalpa (68,145.14 t) and Potrerillos (9,205 t)
This resulted in a reduction of the releases of UPOPs estimated at 89.00 g - TEQ.

description.narrative: Number of municipal waste disposal sites with adequate management practices (non-burn)

comment.narrative: Usually in the country the burning of solid waste at the disposal stage is a voluntary practice, and occasionally happens accidentally.
5 municipal pilot projects implementing integral management of solid wastes including non-burning practices of wastes in domestic and landfill area.

9 pilot municipalities continue pursuing the aim of providing environmentally safe disposal options other than the burning of wastes.
To date nine (9) municipalities have had project support (Tegucigalpa, Comayagua and Potrerillos) which properly manage their landfills in compliance with the formulated master plans. Siguateque and the Association of 5 Municipalities (COLOSUCA) are pilot projects as well, despite they don’t have a regulated landfill, the project has supported in the development, implementation and monitoring of their Municipal Solid Waste Master Plans and capacity building of municipal staff to adopt BAT/BEP to decrease practice of burning of waste in open. The project has also supported these 9 municipalities in awareness raising through public campaigns (radio messages, billboards, educational fairs, among others).

description.narrative: Promoción del Programa de Desarrollo de Proveedores en Honduras

title.narrative: Revisión Externa de Medio Término del Programa de Desarrollo de Proveedores (PDP)

description.narrative: Implantada la Metodologia de Desarrollo Proveedores en 250 empresas proveedores y 25 empresas tractoras quienes fortalecen su red de proveeduría

description.narrative: # de reuniones de trabajo organizadas para elaborar propuestas para el Acuerdo Nacional # de miembros del Grupo de Diálogo Democrático participando en las reuniones de trabajo para elaborar propuestas # de propuestas para el Acuerdo Nacional elaboradas por el Grupo de Diálogo Democrático # de nuevos partidos políticos incluidos en la Mesa de Diálogo entre Partidos # de reuniones de la Mesa de Diálogo entre Partidos con la participación de los 4 nuevos partidos organizados # de propuestas presentadas ante la Mesa de Diálogo entre Partidos # de estudios, análisis y actividades de incidencia llevadas a cabo por USI - CVR # de ejercicios de Transmisión Rápida de Resultados Preliminares (TREP) conducidos Nivel de satisfacción con el desempeño y servicios proporcionados al TSE por parte del Equipo de Asistencia técnica Internacional

comment.narrative: Se forma un grupo de Diálogo Democrático compuesto por 18 líderes de la Sociedad Civil y los partidos políticos, para elaborar propuestas para un acuerdo nacional amplio Se encuentra operando una Mesa de Diálogo entre Partidos integrada por 5 partidos políticos históricos USI-CVR es creada para dar seguimiento a las recomendaciones de la CVR No se practicaron ejercicios TREP durante las últimas elecciones El Equipo de Asistencia Técnica para TSE ha sido establecido y está operando

- 10 miembros del Grupo de Diálogo Democrático participan en las reuniones de trabajo para el análisis de país y para la elaboración de propuestas - 12 reuniones del Grupo de Diálogo Democrático se organizan para elaborar análisis y propuestas de trabajo - 2 reuniones con la Plataforma Institucional para la elaboración de propuestas y acuerdos - 2 reuniones con partidos políticos, sociedad civil y Tribunal Supremo Electoral (bilaterales y generales) para la generación de acuerdos en los temas relacionados con la reforma electoral - 2 jornadas de capacitación para diputadas del Congreso Nacional con el fin de fortalecer su participación en su labor parlamentaria - Una propuesta de fortalecimiento institucional del Grupo de Diálogo Ciudadanía Activa - 2 procesos de acompañamiento técnico al nuevo equipo de gobierno (Derechos Humanos y Transparencia) - Un estudio de análisis político-estratégico para la toma de decisiones

- 10 miembros del Grupo de Diálogo Democrático participan en las reuniones de trabajo para el análisis de país y para la elaboración de propuestas - 12 reuniones del Grupo de Diálogo Democrático se organizan para elaborar análisis y propuestas de trabajo - 2 reuniones con partidos políticos, sociedad civil y Tribunal Supremo Electoral (bilaterales y generales) para la generación de acuerdos en los temas relacionados con la reforma electoral - 2 jornadas de capacitación para diputadas del Congreso Nacional con el fin de fortalecer su participación en su labor parlamentaria - Una propuesta de fortalecimiento institucional del Grupo de Diálogo Ciudadanía Activa

description.narrative: Defence - policy, planning and administration
Delivering multiple global environmental benefits through sustainable management of production landscapes
Delivering multiple global environmental benefits through sustainable management of production landscapes
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To mainstream biodiversity conservation, sustainable land management and carbon sequestration objectives into production landscapes and sectors in humid broadleaved and dry zone agroecosystems

Improvements in connectivity indices in Texiguat-Pico Pijol (T-PP) and Pico Pijol-Montaña de Yoro (PP-MY) corridors in Target area 1, covering 1,200km2.
- Nearest neighbour index indicates distance between patches (low values are good for connectivity)
- Juxtaposition index indicates homogeneity of distribution of vegetation patches throughout the landscape (high values are good for connectivity)

comment.narrative:
Nearest neighbour index for patches of woodland and fallow:
- 27,0 in T-PP
- 46,7 in PP-MY
Juxtaposition index for patches of woodland and fallow:
- 83,7 in T-PP
58,9 in PP-MY

Nearest neighbour index for patches of woodland and fallow:
- 24,0 in T-PP
- 42,0 in PP-MY
Juxtaposition index for patches of woodland and fallow:
- 90,0 in T-PP
65,0 in PP-MY
No progress to date

description.narrative: Increased occurrence in Texiguat-Pico Pijol and Pico Pijol-Montaña de Yoro corridors of jaguars (Panthera onca), of importance for trophic conditions in neighbouring PAs

comment.narrative: Baseline values to be determined at project startup
Target values to be determined at project startup
No progress to date, this baseline study is scheduled for the first semester of 2016.

comment.narrative: Year 4: 1,3590, Increase: 4215
No progress to date

description.narrative: Reductions in assumed soil erosion rates in 600 farms in Target Area 2, due to introduction of silvopastoral systems and more sustainable cropping systems (SPS)

comment.narrative:
Year 5 (t/ year): 214.800
Net reduction over years 2-5 (t): -203.061
No progress to date

description.narrative: Increases in assumed carbon sequestration (tCO2eq) in 650 target farms in Target Area 1 and 600 target farms of Target Area 2, due to introduction of SPS and more sustainable cropping systems

comment.narrative:
Year 0 (tCO2eq/year):
Target Area 1: 49.428
Target Area 2: 25.003

Year 5 (tCO2eq/year):
Target Area 1: 80.118
Target Area 2: 41.623 Total net benefit over 5 years (tCO2eq):
Target Area 1: 36.827
Target Area 2: 19.944
No progress to date

description.narrative: Favorable enabling conditions (policies, markets and finance) exist for delivering multiple global environmental benefits in managed landscapes
Percentage of beef and milk purchases of retailers and exporters that are subject to environmental sustainability criteria

comment.narrative: 20% of meat and milk products (1.700t/year of meat and 22 million litres/year of milk)
No progress to date

description.narrative: Volume of beef and milk purchases to which retailers and exporters have committed (through private sector policies, publications and written agreements) to apply environmental sustainability criteria by 5 years following the end of the project

comment.narrative: 0 (Walmart has made general commitments to supporting small farmers and sustainable agriculture in Central America)

Retailers and exporters have committed through publications and written agreements to applying environmental sustainability criteria to 2,100t/year of beef and 28 million litres/year of milk (25% of their purchases by 5 years after project end)
No progress to date

description.narrative: Volume of finance provided for ranching that is subject to criteria of environmental sustainability (including non-encroachment on natural ecosystems or tree-rich agroecosystems)

comment.narrative: Target area 1: $2.3 million disbursed to 540 producers covering 23,000ha. Target area 2: $2.0 million disbursed to 490 producers covering 21,000ha
No progress to date

description.narrative: Multiple global environmental benefits (biodiversity conservation, reduced land degradation, reduced carbon emissions and increased carbon storage) are delivered in production landscapes in the humid broadleaved forest zone (Region 1) and the dry forest agroecosystem of the south and southwest (Region 2)
Increase in Knowledge, Attitude, Practices (KAP) indices (to be defined at project start) among target farmers (650 in Target Area 1 and 600 in Target Area 2)

comment.narrative: To be determined at start up
To be determined at start up
No progress to date, this KAP study will be ready for the first quarter of 2016

description.narrative: Area of pastures in target areas converted to silvopastoral systems (SPS) with on-farm benefits (for habitat and connectivity in target area 1 and sustainable land management in target area 2, and increased carbon content in both)

comment.narrative:
Target area 1:
An estimated 567ha SSP in 650 target farms
Target area 2:
An estimated 556ha SSP in 600 target farms, covering 18,211ha

Target area 1:
An estimated 3,741ha SSP in 650 target farms, (an increase of 3,174ha) Target area 2:
An estimated 3,703ha SSP in 600 target farms, covering 18,211ha (an increase of 3,147ha)
No progress to date

description.narrative: Length of structurally and compositionally diverse live fences in 650 target farms of Target Area 1 in order to deliver BD connectivity benefits and generate productivity benefits for farmers

comment.narrative: 591km (estimate, to be confirmed at project start)
967km (an increase of 376km)
No progress to date, this baseline data and targets will be confirmed in the first quarter of 2016

description.narrative: Length of structurally and compositionally diverse live fences in 600 target farms of Target Area 2 to generate productivity benefits for farmers

comment.narrative: 943km (estimate, to be confirmed to project start)
1.218km (an increase of 275km)
No progress to date, this baseline data and targets will be confirmed in the first quarter of 2016

description.narrative: Reduction in area of forests or tree rich agroecosystems outside of target farms directly or indirectly affected by expansion of ranching (through displacement, fattening or transhumance), due to insertion in sustainable value chains and improved governance conditions

comment.narrative:
Target area 1
Approximately 100ha/year of forest (with 130tC/ha) converted to pasture (with 1tC/ha), resulting in loss of 64,500tC stock over project lifetime
Target area 2
Approximately 200ha/year of agroecosystem on hills (with 3.6tC/ha) converted to pasture (with 1tC/ha) due to displacement of ranching by commercial crops on lowlands, resulting in loss of 2,610tC stock over project lifetime

Target area 1
Approximately 50ha/year of forest converted to pasture, resulting in avoided loss of 250ha of forest agroecosystem (net benefit of 32,250tC stock) over project lifetime
Target area 2
Approximately 100ha/year of agroecosystem on hills converted to pasture due to displacement of ranching by commercial crops on lowlands, resulting in avoided loss of 500ha of agroecosystem (net benefit of 1,305tC stock) over project lifetime
No progress to date

description.narrative: Reduction in seasonal variations in milk production in target farms

comment.narrative:
Target area 1:
13% seasonal variation in milk production in 650 target farms
Target area 2:
41% seasonal variation in milk production in 600 target farms

Target area 1:
6% seasonal variation in milk production in 650 target farms
Target area 2:
23% seasonal variation in milk production in 600 target farms
No progress to date

description.narrative: Increases in productivity of farms due to introduction of SPS

comment.narrative:
Target area 1:
1,824t/yr of beef and 19 million litres/yr of milk in 650 target farms, Target area 2:
1,408t/yr of beef and 15.6 million t/yr of milk in 600 target farms

2,066t/yr of beef (an increase of 242t/year) and 22.5 million litres/yr of milk (an increase of 3.5 million litres/year) in 650 target farms Target area 2:
1,602t/yr of beef (an increase of 194t/yr) and 18.5 million kg/yr of milk (an increase of 2.9 million litres/yr) in 600 target farms
No progress to date

El Programa Conjunto tiene como propósito impulsar el desarrollo económico local y reducir la pobreza a través de la generación de empleos, empleabilidad y emprendimientos para mujeres y jóvenes en condiciones especiales de vulnerabilidad

Desarrollar agendas y estrategias para el desarrollo económico local de los territorios priorizados de Danlí, El Progreso, Omoa, Tela, La Ceiba y la Mancomunidad del Norte de Francisco Morazán (MANOFM).

policy, planning and administration
“Mejorar las condiciones de vida, facilitar el acceso a ingresos y empleo y reposicionar la cultura lenca entre la población de 5 departamentos del país de origen lenca.
El proposito del Programa es el de apoyar a los gobiernos locales en el tema de desarrollo económico inclusivo dando continuidad a las acciones para el alcance las ODMS despues de 2015

description.narrative: Mejorar la seguridad ciudadana mediante el fortalecimiento de las capacidades locales y nacionales para la implementacion de intervenciones basadas en evidencias que atiendan los factores de riesgo en materia de criminalidad y violencia.

Fortalecimiento de las capacidades institucionales de la Presidencia de la República, a través de la implementación del Sistema de Gestión para la Gobernabilidad (SIGOB)

El objetivo del proyecto es fortalecer las capacidades institucionales del Gabinete Presidencial a través de la implementación del Centro de Gestión del Presidente y de la Presidencia de la República, a través de la implementación de sistemas de trabajo.

title.narrative: Early Recovery Project of Drought in Dry Corridor

description.narrative: Apoyo a la coordinación de la ayuda humanitaria en municipios afectados en el corredor seco bajo un enfoque de derechos humanos. Además una estrategia de recuperación temprana por la pérdida de los medios de vida de subsistencia de la población afectada.
